indicators.justification:
Armenia reports emission information under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), providing information on national circumstances, greenhouse gas inventory, progress in mitigation policies and actions, reporting and verification system, as well as on support received and needed (1). The data can be found on the website of the Ministry of Environment (2), as well as in the published inventory reports (3), biennial update reports (4), and national communication reports (5). The data, however, is not available in a machine-readable format.

Sources
(1): http://www.nature-ic.am/en/publications/NationalReports/0/0
(2): http://www.mnp.am/en/environment/emissions
(3): Ministry of Environment. (2020). National Greenhouse Gas Inventory Report of Armenia 1990-2017, https://unfccc.int/sites/default/files/resource/NIR_2017_Armenia.pdf
(4): Ministry of Environment. (2021). Armenia's Third Biennial Update Report, https://unfccc.int/sites/default/files/resource/BUR3_Armenia.pdf
(5): Ministry of Environment. (2020). The Fourth National Communication on Climate Change, https://unfccc.int/sites/default/files/resource/NC4_Armenia_.pdf

evidence.title: National Greenhouse Gas Inventory Report of Armenia 1990-2017
The Fourth National Communication on Climate Change

indicators.justification:
The Red Books of Animals and Plants is published on the website of the Ministry of Environment of the Republic of Armenia(1).
The Red Book of Armenia mobile application developed by the Ministry contains information on the species registered in the Red Books of Plants and Animals of the Republic of Armenia (2). It presents the biological classification, number, places of habitat and distribution, morphology of the registered species. An interactive map shows the prevalence of these species (3).

Sources
(1): http://www.mnp.am/shrjaka-mijavayr/karmir-girq
(2): https://bit.ly/3ile0nV 
(3): http://www.mnp.am/en/news/the-red-book-of-armenia-mobile-application-containing-information-on-the-species-registered-in-the-red-books-of-plants-and-animals-of-the-republic-of-armenia-has-been-run

indicators.justification:
The Fourth National Communication on Climate Change discusses projections, vulnerability assessment, and adaptation measures. Particularly, air temperature change, annual precipitation change, frequency and intensity of natural disasters, drought indices are presented and analyzed. 
For the projection of changes in air temperature and atmospheric precipitation, the results of the CCSM4 Global Climate Model were reviewed, as well as high-resolution METRAS (12x12km) regional climate model was applied. 
Analysis of water resources vulnerability in Armenia was carried out using the CCSM4 model data with the emission scenarios of RCP8.5 and RCP6.0, as well as the METRAS model with the RCP8.5 scenario (1).

Sources
(1): Ministry of Environment. (2020). The Fourth National Communication on Climate Change, https://unfccc.int/sites/default/files/resource/NC4_Armenia_.pdf

evidence.title: The Fourth National Communication on Climate Change

indicators.justification:
Armenia has made a commitment to beneficial ownership transparency in an Open Government Partnership National Action Plan (1). The country is also a member of the Beneficial Ownership Leadership Group (2; 3). 
To introduce a beneficial ownership register (4), Armenia adopted a "one-sector-first" approach (5). As an Extractives Industry Transparency Initiative (EITI) member, the country has prioritized beneficial ownership disclosures for the extractives sector (6). As part of its disclosure pilot, Armenia published beneficial ownership data from mining firms in spring 2020 (7).
For some mining companies, data is accessible in machine-readable JSON format, although users can only download information for one company at a time (8). 

Sources
(1): Armenia OGP Action Plan 2018-2020, https://www.opengovpartnership.org/documents/armenia-action-plan-2018-2020/
(2): www.openownership.org
(3): https://www.openownership.org/what-we-do/the-beneficial-ownership-leadership-group/
(4): https://bo.e-register.am/en/auth
(5): Open Ownership. (2020). Beneficial Ownership Transparency in Armenia, Scoping Study, Retrieved on July 26th, 2021 from https://www.openownership.org/uploads/armenia-scoping-report.pdf
(6): https://www.eiti.am/en/beneficial-ownership-dislosure
(7): https://www.eiti.am/hy/%D4%BB%D5%8D-%D5%B0%D5%A1%D5%B5%D5%BF%D5%A1%D6%80%D5%A1%D6%80%D5%A1%D5%A3%D5%A5%D6%80/?tab=88
(8): https://www.e-register.am/en/companies/1272761/declaration/c51e08a7-6fdb-4ab7-a55c-c74a68a8f54c

evidence.title: Beneficial Ownership Transparency in Armenia, Scoping Study, Aug 2020

indicators.justification:
State Register of the Legal Entities of the Ministry of Justice of the Republic of Armenia maintains an Electronic Register where one can submit online applications for registration of legal entities, track applications and search existing companies and purchase full information about any company (1). Users can access a limited summary of information on companies without paying the fee. No open dataset is available. 
The existing company data on Armenia's e-register is available on a per-record basis in a structured form in XML format (2).

Sources
(1): Electronic State Register of the Legal Entities of the Ministry of Justice of the Republic of Armenia, https://www.e-register.am/en/
(2): Open Ownership. (2020). Beneficial Ownership Transparency in Armenia, Scoping Study, Retrieved on July 26th, 2021 from https://www.openownership.org/uploads/armenia-scoping-report.pdf

indicators.justification:
The Civil Status Acts Registration Agency (CSARA) of the Ministry of Justice of the Republic of Armenia is responsible for civil registration (1). Armenia's modern CRVS is fully digitized, with all registered information being entered directly into the electronic civil register. The system enables easier data sharing and registration of vital events (2). CSARA data is not available online but is accessible by other state agencies through APIs with the help of the operator agency- EKENG CJSC (3).

Vital statistics are produced by the Statistical Committee of Armenia (4) and relies on two resources: 
1) Medical data for vital statistics extracted and sent automatically to the Committee through the e-health system (5); 
2) Other data linked to the registration of vital events received directly from Civil Status Acts Registration Agency (2).

Sources
(1): https://www.moj.am/en/services/civil_registry/item/518
(2): The Center of Excellence for CRVS Systems. (2020). Snapshot of CRVS System of Armenia, Report;  https://crvssystems.ca/sites/default/files/assets/images/CRVS_Armenia_e_WEB%20(2).pdf
(3): https://www.ekeng.am/en/sub/e_manage
(4): https://armstat.am/en/?nid=209
(5): https://www.armed.am/en/auth/loginnew

evidence.title: The Centre of Excellence for CRVS Systems. (2020). Snapshot of CRVS
Statistical Committee of the Republic of Armenia, Demographic Database

indicators.justification:
The United Information System of Electronic Healthcare in the Republic of Armenia (ARMED) is a comprehensive and synchronous data-transmission platform for three types of data: clinical, administrative, and financial (1). The platform presents the capacity of the healthcare system, particularly information about vacant beds in medical institutions according to departments (2).

Sources
(1): https://armed.am/en/auth/loginnew
(2): https://armed.am/publicdata/?pg=freebeds

indicators.justification:
Information on vaccinations is available in the form of news reports published every Monday by the Ministry of Health. Information concerns the number of people vaccinated, number of first and second doses administered (1). No open data on specific aspects of vaccination, including demographic information, is available.

Sources

indicators.justification:
Providing information on property rights and restrictions is one of the main functions of the Cadastre Committee of the Republic of Armenia (1). Data on land tenure, including geospatial reference, can be obtained from the e-services platform of the Cadastre Committee for an official fee. It is not available as open data.

Sources
(1): https://www.cadastre.am/provide-information
(2): https://www.e-cadastre.am/

indicators.justification:
The Corruption Prevention Commission maintains the Declaration Registry, which is an electronic system of declarations on property and income of high-ranking officials and affiliated persons in Armenia (1). The information is not available in the open data format yet. However, one of the country's commitments to Open Government Partnership (OGP) is to ensure the availability of open data in official declarations (2). 

Sources
(1): Declaration Registry, http://cpcarmenia.am/en/declarations-registry/
(2): Open Government Partnership (OGP) commitments, https://www.opengovpartnership.org/members/armenia/commitments/AM0030/

indicators.justification:
Government Decree N-403-N of April 20th, 2017, defines the procedure for publishing and submitting the report by parties on financial means, spending, and property, and provides the respective templates (1). According to the decree, the parties publish their financial reports on the official website of public announcements- azdarar.am (2). The reports use the structured report template; they are, however published only in the pdf format.

Sources
(1): Government Decree N-403-N of April 20th, 2017; https://www.arlis.am/DocumentView.aspx?docID=112900

indicators.justification:
The unified portal for online requests (e-request) helps citizens submit online applications, requests, or complaints to state authorities without visiting them, track their inquiry, and receive answers through the portal (1). The portal offers basic statistics of inquiries in aggregated form.

Sources
(1): https://e-request.am/en

indicators.justification:
In Armenia, drafts of normative legal acts are published on a unified online platform - e-draft. The platform allows public agencies to present their draft regulations to the public and organize online public consultations. Users can post suggestions, see the summary of suggestions, conclusions, and changes made in response to suggestions (1).

Sources
(1): https://www.e-draft.am/en

indicators.justification:
Public Procurement data is openly accessible at the ARMEPS platform of the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Armenia (1). The system allows searching for data by procurement plans or contracts, viewing graphical reports, and generating detailed reports using the templates available in the system.

indicators.justification:
A few hackathons have been organized by CSOs and International organizations in collaboration with the Government. For instance, the Open Data Hackathon by Kolba Lab aimed at using government data to generate innovative solutions to a range of Armenia's social challenges (1). Open Government Data Hackathon, organized by Public Journalism Club NGO with the support of the US Embassy in Armenia, aimed to develop ideas that would coincide with Armenia's commitments under the Open Government Partnership.

Sources
(1): http://kolba.am/events/winners-of-open-data-hackathon/
(2): https://pjc.am/portfolio/bac-karavarman-ev-tvyalneri-heqeton/?lang=en

indicators.justification:
The Republic of Armenia joined the Open Government Partnership (OGP) initiative on 17 October 2011. The commitments included in the OGP action plans cover social, legal, financial, community, mining, and other sectors. In the fourth Action Plan (2018-2020), Armenia has committed to developing "Open data" in official declarations by improving the electronic system of declarations on property, income, and affiliated persons of high-ranking officials (1).
However, there is no explicit open data initiative in the country led by the government.

Sources
(1): https://www.opengovpartnership.org/documents/armenia-action-plan-2018-2020/

responses.response_text: There is no evidence of any government-led open government data initiative in the country.
responses.subquestion_text: Has there been any form of government-led open government data initiative during the study period?
There is a government team in place supporting open data activities.
There is an allocated budget for open data activities.
There is a well-maintained open data portal.
There is guidance and support for government publication of open data.
Senior political leaders back the open data initiative.

indicators.justification:
Yerevan municipality (the capital city) has been developing data management tools within its "Smart City" concept. One of those tools is the interactive budget where users can find data on the city expenses (1). No evidence from other regional or local governments.

Source
(1): https://budget.yerevan.am/

responses.response_text: The examples given are exceptions: the majority of cities and regions do not have the capacity to effectively manage data.
responses.subquestion_text: How widespread are local capacities to effectively manage data?

indicators.justification:
The Civil Service Office of the Staff of the Prime Minister of the Republic of Armenia is going to offer training for civil servants on Data Collection and Analysis starting from September 2021 (1). The Civil Service Office recognizes data gathering and analysis as a core competency for civil servants (2). The training will have both in-person and remote modules. The training is mandatory for all civil servants of the country. The Public Administration Academy of RA won the bid to conduct the training (3). 

Sources
(1): https://cso.gov.am/training-programs
(2): https://cso.gov.am/sections/competence
(3): Phone Interview with a representative of the Civil Service Office of the Staff of the Prime Minister of the Republic of Armenia

evidence.title: Training for Civil Servants on Data Collection and Analysis

indicators.justification: Although there are a number of datasets in Armenia that are interoperable, there is no evidence of interoperability across political integrity datasets.

responses.response_text: The datasets do not share common identifiers.
responses.subquestion_text: There is evidence that datasets share common identifiers.

The different political integrity datasets use common identifiers for public officials.
Lobbying data and political finance data share common identifiers for lobbyist clients and party and campaign donors.
Lobbying registers and public consultation data use common identifiers for regulations.
Asset declarations and political finance disclosures share common identifiers for interests, assets, and liabilities.
The various datasets share common identifiers for legal persons associated with donations, interests, assets, liabilities, and lobbying activities.
The key datasets for the political integrity and company information modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and land modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and public finance modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and public procurement modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.

responses.response_text: There is no consistency of identifiers or identification systems.

indicators.justification:
The Government of Armenia has approved a package of law amendments aiming to expand the scope of entities obliged to disclose their beneficial owners (1).
Currently, the government piloted a beneficial ownership register for mining companies in the country in the framework of the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative (EITI) (2). According to the 4th Open Government Partnership (OGP) Action plan of Armenia, the Government is committed to launching a comprehensive open and freely accessible register of beneficial ownership (3; 4). Armenia has made a commitment to beneficial ownership transparency also as part of the Beneficial Ownership Leadership Group (5).

Sources
(1): Government Approval on the Package of Law Amendments, Government Session of 22 April 2021, Item 42, https://www.e-gov.am/sessions/archive/2021/04/22/
(2): Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative, "The Government Approved the Package of Laws for Disclosure of Beneficial Owners in Armenia", 22 April 2021, Retrieved on July 22th, 2021 from https://www.eiti.am/en/news/2021/04/22/the-government-approved-the-package-of-laws-for-disclosure-of-beneficial-owners-in-armenia/105/ 
(3): Armenia OGP Action Plan 2018-2020, https://www.opengovpartnership.org/documents/armenia-action-plan-2018-2020/
(4): Armenia Transitional Results Report 2018-2020, https://www.opengovpartnership.org/documents/armenia-transitional-results-report-2018-2020/
(5): The Beneficial Ownership Leadership Group, https://www.openownership.org/what-we-do/the-beneficial-ownership-leadership-group/

evidence.title: The Government Approved the Package of Laws for Disclosure of Beneficial Owners in Armenia
Government Approval on the Package of Law Amendments

indicators.justification:
According to Government decree N1093 (1), when developing electronic systems, Government agencies should strive to make full use of existing technologies to create inclusive tools to overcome the socio-economic exclusion of users from the system. The decree specifies that the goal of accessibility is to provide people with disabilities and elderly people with the same adequate level of access to public services as other citizens.

Sources
(1):RA Government Decree N1093 on "Defining security, interoperability and general technical requirements for electronic systems used for provision of electronic services or implementation of other actions by state and local government bodies", 31 August 2015, https://www.arlis.am/documentview.aspx?docid=152169

responses.response_text: A framework exists and has the force of law.
responses.subquestion_text: What is the nature of the framework?

responses.response_text: There is either a dedicated framework for accessibility coverage related to data or a framework that includes specific provisions related to accessibility coverage and data.
responses.subquestion_text: Where does this requirement exist?
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
How comprehensive, in terms of jurisdiction, is the coverage of the laws, regulations, policies, or guidance assessed for this question?

indicators.justification:
According to Government Decree N1093 on "Defining the requirements to security, interoperability and general technical requirements of electronic systems used for the provision of electronic services or implementation of other actions by state and local government bodies" (August 31, 2015), if state bodies connect and exchange information between their information systems within the limits prescribed by law, it should be based on systems created by open standards. The decree specifies the open standards that government agencies should apply when exchanging data with other government agencies or individuals.

Sources
(1): RA Government Decree N1093 of August 31, 2015; 
https://www.arlis.am/DocumentView.aspx?docID=110384

evidence.title: RA Government Decree N1093 of August 31, 2015

responses.response_text: A framework exists and has the force of law.

There are minimum standards for metadata when government data is catalogued or published.
There is a standardised process for publishing and updating published government data.

There are clearly documented processes for soliciting and integrating feedback from external users to improve data quality.

responses.response_text: The data management approaches assessed generally apply across the whole public sector.
responses.subquestion_text: How broadly is good data management practice established?

indicators.justification:
Government decree N1093 of August 31, 2015, establishes the general security, interoperability, and technical requirements for electronic systems used for the provision or operation of electronic information services by state and local government bodies, including the relationship to the technical requirements required to connect to these systems by natural and legal persons(1).
The government decree of the Republic of Armenia N1849 of December 19th, 2019 regulates the transfer of electronically stored and processed personal data by state and local self-government bodies, between these bodies, as well as to RA resident legal entities and investment funds. The decision also regulates the processes of the interconnection of databases. According to the decree, the data contained in the databases are transferred to state and local government bodies free of charge(2).
Interconnection to databases of state and local self-government bodies is possible by any resident legal entity or investment fund of RA if a properly completed application for access to such databases is submitted to the operator, approved, and the contract is signed with the operator in compliance with the minimum safety requirements established and applied by the Operator (EKENG CJSC) for technical connection based on the general requirements of the Government decision N 1093 of August 31, 2015 (1; 3).

Sources
(1): RA Government Decree on "Defining security, interoperability and general technical requirements for electronic systems used for the provision of electronic services or implementation of other actions by state and local government bodies", 31 August 2015, N1093,  
https://www.arlis.am/documentview.aspx?docID=110384
(2): RA Government Decree on "Establishing the procedure of personal data sharing through electronic information system", 19 December 2019, N1849  
https://www.arlis.am/DocumentView.aspx?DocID=137681
(3): e-Governance infrastructure implementation agency, Databases, Retrieved on July 16th, 2021 from https://www.ekeng.am/en/sub/e_manage

indicators.justification:
Armenia adopted the Law on Protection of Personal Data on May 18th, 2015 (1). It was followed by the Prime Minister's decree approving the list of measures to ensure the implementation of the law (2).

The Agency for Protection of Personal Data of the Ministry of Justice of the Republic of Armenia is the authorized state body for the protection of personal data. The Agency ensures:
1. maintenance of the registry for those processing personal data;
2. protection of the rights of subjects of relations connected with the protection of personal data;
3. within the scope of its competence, lawful processing of personal data.

The Agency has published guides on children's personal data, video surveillance, personal data related to labor relations, the protection of personal data on social media, among others.

Sources
(1): RA Law on Protection of Personal Data, 18 May 2015
(2): RA Prime Minister's Decree N573A
(3): Statute of the Agency for Protection of Personal Data of The Ministry of Justice of the Republic of Armenia, Retrieved on July 22th, 2021 from https://www.moj.am/en/structures/view/structure/32

evidence.title: The Law of the Republic of Armenia on Protection of Personal Data
RA Prime Minister's Decree (July 3th, 2015, N573A) on Approval of the List of Measures Ensuring the Implementation of the Law on Personal Data Protection
The Agency for Protection of Personal Data  of the Ministry of Justice of the Republic of Armenia

indicators.justification:
According to the Government Decree N1093, the primary language used in each created information system must be the official language of the Republic of Armenia - Armenian (1).

The same decree also mentions that Government agencies should build linguistically neutral information systems, which should enable the provision of multilingual services in the event of the establishment of international services. From a practical point of view, the systems should be designed in a way that they can provide interfaces in at least 3 languages ​​(Armenian, Russian, and English) (1).

Sources
(1): RA Government Decree N1093 on "Defining security, interoperability and general technical requirements for electronic systems used for the provision of electronic services or implementation of other actions by state and local government bodies", August 31, 2015; https://www.arlis.am/documentview.aspx?docid=152169

indicators.justification:
Armenia does not have a law on open data yet. Armenia's Digitalization Strategy 2021-2025, adopted in February 2021, highlights the importance of creating an enabling environment for the implementation of the strategy. The development of data policy is mentioned as one of the conditions of digitalization. The policy will define data classifications in Armenia, as a result of which the government will formulate its approaches to open data policy (1). 

Sources 
(1): RA Government Decree on Approval of Armenia's Digitalization Strategy, Action Plan, and Results Indicators, Part IV, Section 7, 2021. https://www.arlis.am/DocumentView.aspx?DocID=149957

evidence.title: RA Government Decree on Approval of Armenia's Digitalization Strategy, Action Plan and Results Indicators

The framework promotes training and capacity building among government officials.

indicators.justification:
Article 26 of the Law on the Budgetary System of the Republic of Armenia ensures the publicity of the development, discussion, and approval of the draft state budget, implementation of the state budget law and its verification (1). The Ministry of Finance sets out guidelines and provides templates for collecting and reporting data on state and community budgets (2). 
In November 2019, the Government of Armenia approved the strategy and action plan to implement the Public Finance Management (PFM) system reform for 2019-2023 (3). The reform will improve the efficiency of the public expenditure management system and the quality of services provided (4). 

Sources
(1): The Law on the Budgetary System of the Republic of Armenia, 1997 http://www.parliament.am/law_docs/210797HO137eng.pdf
(2): The Order N254-N of the Ministry of Finance of March 13, 2019 
https://minfin.am/website/images/website/iravakan_akter/hramanner/byujetayin/254-N%20(2).pdf
(3): The Strategy and the Action Plan of Public Finance Management (PFM) System Reform for 2019-2023
https://www.e-gov.am/gov-decrees/item/33133/
(4): https://www.gov.am/en/news/item/9647/

indicators.justification:
The Law on Public Service of the Republic of Armenia, adopted in 2018, requires the collection and publication of the interests and assets of public officials (1). The Corruption Prevention Commission of the Republic of Armenia, an autonomous state body, is responsible for regulating the process of declaration and inspecting and analyzing the declarations (2). The Commission has adopted decisions and guidelines on the procedures of declarations (3).

indicators.justification:
The Law of the Republic of Armenia on Parties, adopted in 2016, requires the parties to submit their financial and accounting reports. The reports specifying sources of the financial means, spending as well as property, should be published on mass media and then presented to the Central Electoral Commission.
Government Decree N-403-N of April 20th, 2017 defines the procedure for publishing and submitting the report by parties on financial means, spending, and property, and provides the respective templates (2).

Sources
(1): The Law of the Republic of Armenia on Parties, 2016; https://www.arlis.am/documentview.aspx?docid=110534
(2): Government Decree N-403-N of April 20th, 2017; https://www.arlis.am/DocumentView.aspx?docID=112900

evidence.title: The Law of the Republic of Armenia on Parties

responses.subquestion_text: Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?

responses.response_text: Requirements to publish data are set out in binding policy, regulations, or law.
responses.subquestion_text: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations, or guidance discuss the publication of open data?
The framework contains clear and unambiguous definitions of campaigning activities of parties, candidates, and third parties.

responses.response_text: The framework requires the public disclosure of the identity of every donor.
responses.subquestion_text: The framework requires donors' identities be made public.
The framework requires collecting specific information on financial contributions.
The framework requires collecting specific information on assets and liabilities.
The framework requires collecting specific information on income and spending.
The framework requires collecting specific information on in-kind and non-financial support.
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
The framework requires regular updates, including updates in conjunction with campaigns and defined campaign schedules.
The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.
How comprehensive, in terms of jurisdiction, is the coverage of the laws, regulations, policies, or guidance assessed for this question?

indicators.justification:
The Law on the Normative Legal Acts of the Republic of Armenia states that draft legislative acts are subject to public discussion, except for the draft law on ratification (accession) of an international treaty (1). Government Decree N1146-N of October 10, 2018, on Organizing and Conducting Public Consultations defines the procedure of public consultations (2).

Sources
(1): The Law on the Normative Legal Acts of the Republic of Armenia; 
(2): Government Decree N1146-N of October 10, 2018; http://www.irtek.am/views/act.aspx?aid=150549

evidence.title: The Law on the Normative Legal Acts of the Republic of Armenia

responses.subquestion_text: Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?

responses.response_text: Requirements to publish data are set out in binding policy, regulations, or law.
responses.subquestion_text: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations, or guidance discuss the publication of open data?
The framework requires the publication of notice of intent in advance of public consultation processes.
The framework requires the publication of proposed regulations.
The framework requires the timely publication of a full set of public comments generated through public consultation processes.
The framework requires reasoned responses to be published alongside comments.
The framework requires the publication of final regulations and justification.
The framework requires the publication of challenges to laws and regulations that have undergone public consultation processes, as well as their results.
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.
How comprehensive, in terms of jurisdiction, is the coverage of the laws, regulations, policies, or guidance assessed for this question?

indicators.justification:
In October 2015, based on the Law of the Republic of Armenia on Freedom of Information (1), the Government of Armenia adopted a regulation on the information provision by state bodies with the aim of improving the implementation of Freedom of Information legislation (2). The regulation was amended in 2018 (3). According to the regulation, public entities are required to publish the basic statistics of requests.

Sources
(1): The Law of the Republic of Armenia on Freedom of Information; http://www.parliament.am/legislation.php?sel=show&ID=1390&lang=arm&enc=utf8
(2): Government Decree N1204-N of October 15, 2015; https://www.arlis.am/documentview.aspx?docid=101115
(3): Government Decree N524-N of April 26, 2018; https://www.arlis.am/documentview.aspx?docid=122073

evidence.title: The Law of the Republic of Armenia on Freedom of Information

responses.subquestion_text: Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?

responses.response_text: Requirements to publish this information as open data are set out in binding policy, regulations, or law.
responses.subquestion_text: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations, or guidance discuss the publication of open data?
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding the number of requests submitted and processed.
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding how long it took the relevant government agency or agencies to fill requests.
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding material withheld and the reasons for withholding it.
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding appeals to RTI determinations and their results.
The framework requires that information is linked to the relevant agency, department, or other governmental entity.
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.

responses.response_text: The framework covers the entire public sector.
responses.subquestion_text: How comprehensive, in terms of jurisdiction, is the framework assessed for this question?

indicators.justification: No products or services have been detected that use open company data to support due diligence.

responses.response_text: There is no evidence of such products or services in the country.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of this data being used in products/services?
There is evidence of these products and services being promoted to, or used by, government.
There is evidence of these products/services being promoted to, or used by, civil society
There is evidence of these products/services being promoted to, or used by, the private sector.
There is evidence of these products and services being promoted to, or used by, media.
There is evidence that at least one of the examples cited is making use of beneficial ownership data.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data

indicators.justification:
There is evidence of journalists using data from the Cadastre Committee of the Republic of Armenia to report the misuse of community lands (1). 

Sources
(1): https://hetq.am/hy/article/126824
indicators.indicator_name: Use (L): Influencing policy for gender and inclusion
indicators.indicator_name_medium: Gender and inclusion uses of data
indicators.indicator_name_short: Gender and inclusion uses of data

responses.response_text: There are isolated cases of actors or entities using this kind of data to influence policy in the interests of more equitable land tenure and use.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of this data being used to influence policy in the interests of more equitable land tenure and use?
There is evidence of civil society organizations using data in this way.
There is evidence of media using data in this way.
There is evidence of academics using data in this way.
There is evidence of the private sector using data in this way.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
Is there evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts on land policy?

indicators.justification:
CSOs and media regularly use and analyze data on public officials' income and assets published by the Corruption Prevention Commission at the Declaration registry (1). Data.hetq.am is a public database of Armenian public officials' assets developed by hetq.am. It uses the Declaration registry along with other sources to track the income, properties, and connections of high-ranking officials (2).

Sources
(1): http://cpcarmenia.am/en/declarations-registry/
(2): https://data.hetq.am/en

evidence.title: Hetq.am public database of Armenian public officials assets

responses.response_text: There are isolated cases of actors or entities using this kind of data for accountability purposes, though the source may not be open data.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of this data being used for accountability purposes?
Civil society organizations regularly use this data for accountability purposes.
The media regularly uses this data for accountability purposes.
Scholars or academic institutions regularly use this data for accountability purposes.
The private sector regularly uses this data for accountability purposes.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
There is evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts.

indicators.justification:
Different CSOs use government procurement data from the ARMEPS platform (1) of the Ministry of Finance to monitor and analyze the procurement processes by the Government. For instance, National Center for Public Policy Research (NCPPR) has published reports analyzing trends and monitoring results of public procurement. Similarly, the Freedom of Information Center of Armenia (3) and the Public Journalism Club (4) have publications exploring providers, contracts, and contract amounts of public procurement. 

(1): https://armeps.am/ppcm/public/reports#/home
(2): http://policyobserver.am/%d5%ba%d5%a5%d5%bf%d5%a3%d5%b6%d5%b8%d6%82%d5%b4%d5%b6%d5%a5%d6%80%d5%ab-%d6%87-%d5%a2%d5%b8%d5%b2%d5%b8%d6%84%d5%a1%d6%80%d5%af%d5%b4%d5%a1%d5%b6-%d5%b0%d5%a1%d5%b4%d5%a1%d5%af%d5%a1%d6%80%d5%a3/
(3): http://www.foi.am/hy/articles/item/1873/
(4): https://pjc.am/hratap-mek-andzic-entacakargov-gnumneri-ktruk-ach-pashtpanutyan-nakhararutyunum/

evidence.title: Results of Monitoring of Public Procurement by NCPPR
Article by FOI about Public Procurement
Article by PJC about Public Procrement

responses.response_text: There is evidence of multiple different uses involving different organisations.
responses.subquestion_text: To what extent is there evidence of this kind of data use?
There is evidence of government procurement data being presented through data-driven dashboards.
There is evidence of government procurement data being used for red flag analysis.
There is evidence that government procurement data is being analyzed to improve access to procurement opportunities for marginalized groups.
There is evidence of government procurement data being analysed to support sustainable / environmental procurement.
There are examples of government using data in these ways.
There are examples of civil society using data in these ways.
There is evidence of private sector using data in this way
At least one of the examples cited appears to make use of open procurement data.
At least one of the examples identified makes use of open beneficial ownership data.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
There is evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts.
